verses.text: He that toucheth pitch shall be defiled therewith; And he that hath fellowship with a proud \add man\add* shall be like unto him.

Burden not thyself above thy power while thou livest; And have no fellowship with \add one that is\add* mightier and richer than thyself: \add For\add* how agree the kettle and the earthen pot together? \add For\add* if the one be smitten against the other, it shall be broken.
The rich \add man\add* hath done wrong, and \add yet\add* he threateneth withal: The poor is wronged, and he must intreat also.
If thou be for \add his\add* profit, he will use thee: But if thou have nothing, he will forsake thee.
If thou have \add any thing\add*, he will live with thee: Yea, he will make thee bare, and will not be sorry \add for it\add*.
If he have need of thee, he will deceive thee, And smile upon thee, and put thee in hope; He will speak thee fair, and say, What wantest thou?

And he will shame thee by his meats, Until he have drawn thee dry twice or thrice, And at the last he will laugh thee to scorn: Afterward, when he seeth thee, he will forsake thee, And shake his head at thee.
Beware that thou be not deceived, And brought down in thy jollity.
If thou be invited of a mighty man, withdraw thyself, And so much the more will he invite thee.
Press thou not upon \add him\add*, lest thou be put back; Stand not far off, lest thou be forgotten.
Affect not to be made equal unto him in talk, And believe not his many words: For with much communication will he tempt thee, And smiling upon \add thee\add* will get out thy secrets:
But cruelly he will lay up thy words, And will not spare to do thee hurt, and to put \add thee\add* in prison.
Observe, and take good heed, For thou walkest in peril of thy overthrowing: When thou hearest these \add things\add*, awake in thy sleep.
Love the Lord all \add thy\add* life, And call upon him for thy salvation.
Every beast loveth his like, And every man loveth his neighbor.
All flesh consorteth according to kind, And a man will cleave to his like.
What fellowship hath the wolf with the lamb? So the sinner with the godly.
What agreement \add is there\add* between the hyena and a dog? And what peace between the rich and the poor?
\add As\add* the wild ass \add is\add* the lionsâ€™ prey in the wilderness: So the rich eat up the poor.
\add As\add* the proud hate humility: So doth the rich abhor the poor.
A rich \add man\add* beginning to fall is held up of \add his\add* friends: But a poor \add man\add* being down is thrust also away by \add his\add* friends.

When a rich \add man\add* is fallen, \add he hath\add* many helpers: He speaketh \add things\add* not to be spoken, and \add yet men\add* justify him: The poor \add man\add* slipt, and \add yet\add* they rebuked him too; He spake wisely, and could have no place.

When a rich \add man\add* speaketh, every man holdeth his tongue, And \add look\add*, what he saith, they extol it to the clouds: But if the poor \add man\add* speak, they say, What \add fellow is\add* this? And if he stumble, they will help to overthrow him.
Riches \add are\add* good unto him that hath no sin, And poverty \add is\add* evil in the mouth of the ungodly.
The heart of a man changeth his countenance, whether \add it be\add* for good or evil: And a merry heart maketh a cheerful countenance.
A cheerful countenance \add is\add* a token of a heart \add that is\add* in prosperity; And the finding out of parables \add is\add* a wearisome labour of the mind.
